hiqfermion.ansatzes.ansatz_pairwise module¶

class hiqfermion.ansatzes.ansatz_pairwise.AnsatzPairwise(n_qubits, depth=1, initial_state=None)¶

Bases: hiqfermion.ansatzes.variational_ansatz.VariationalAnsatz

Pairwise entangling ansatz. Proposed in paper arXiv: 1804.054553. Arguments:

Variational_Ansatz – generate the variational ansatz
build_ansatz(params, eng)¶

Construct the variational ansatz

Arguments:

params (numpy.ndarray[float]) – parameters for the ansatz

eng (simulator engine) – a compiler engine

qureg (quantum register) – quantum register for the ansatz (default: {None})

Returns:
Quantum ansatz state: an ansatz state with given parameters
Raises:
The length of params is not matched the number of parameters (self._n_parameters)

hiqfermion.ansatzes.ansatz_quccsd module¶

class hiqfermion.ansatzes.ansatz_quccsd.Q_UCCSD¶

Bases: object

Create a fermionic operator that is the generator of Q_UCCSD. This is a straightforward while not efficient method to generate the Q_UCCSD ansatz.

# this module is to generate the unitary coupled cluster single and double excitations. # the idea is come from the arxiv paper https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevA.98.022322.

static down_index(index, beta)¶

Return the index of spin down electron, here the down_index begin with the boundary of half number of electrons

generator(single_amplitudes, double_amplitudes)¶

“Return the uccsd generator by first generating single excitations and then generating the double excitations. Args:

The single_amplitudes and double_amplitudes are the list
get_packed_amplitudes(single_amplitudes, double_amplitudes, n_qubits, n_electrons)¶

Convert amplitudes for use with Q_UCCSD

The output list contains only those amplitudes that are relevant to Q_UCCSD, in an order suitable for use with the function Q_UCCSD.generator.

Args:
single_amplitudes(ndarray): [N x N] array storing single excitation
amplitudes corresponding to t[i,j] * (a_i^dagger a_j - H.C.)
double_amplitudes(ndarray): [N x N x N x N] array storing double
excitation amplitudes corresponding to t[i,j,k,l] * (a_i^dagger a_j a_k^dagger a_l - H.C.)
n_qubits(int): Number of spin-orbitals used to represent the system,
which also corresponds to number of qubits in a non-compact map.

n_electrons(int): Number of electrons in the physical system.

Returns:
packed_amplitudes(list): List storing the unique single
and double excitation amplitudes for a singlet UCCSD operator. The ordering lists unique single excitations before double excitations.
q_uccsd_convert_amplitude_format(single_amplitudes, double_amplitudes)¶

Re-format single_amplitudes and double_amplitudes from ndarrays to lists, basically to allocate the corresponding index to the value.

signlet_generator(packed_amplitudes, n_qubits, n_electrons)¶

Create a singlet Q_UCCSD generator for a system with n_electrons

This function generates a FermionOperator for a Q_UCCSD generator designed
to act on a reference state (Hartree Fock state) consisting of n_qubits spin orbitals and n_electrons electrons. The initial state is usually a Hartree Fock state.
Args:
packed_amplitudes(list): List storing the unique single
and double excitation amplitudes for a singlet Q_UCCSD operator. The ordering lists unique single excitations before double excitations.
n_qubits(int): Number of spin-orbitals used to represent the system,
which also corresponds to number of qubits in a non-compact map.

n_electrons(int): Number of electrons in the physical system.

Returns:
generator(FermionOperator): Generator of the Q_UCCSD operator that
builds the Q_UCCSD wavefunction.
singlet_param_size(n_qubits, n_electrons)¶

Determine number of independent amplitudes for Q_UCCSD

Args:
n_qubits(int): Number of qubits/spin-orbitals in the system n_electrons(int): Number of electrons in the reference state
Returns:
Number of independent parameters for Q_UCCSD with a reference state(generally should be Hartree Fock state).
static up_index(index)¶

Return the index of spin up electron

hiqfermion.ansatzes.ansatz_uccsd module¶

class hiqfermion.ansatzes.ansatz_uccsd.UCCSD¶

Bases: object

Create a fermionic operator that is the generator of uccsd. This is a straightforward while not efficient method to generate the uccsd ansatz. A good intial amplitude would always generate a relatively good ansatz

down_index(index)¶

Return the index of spin up electron

generator(single_amplitudes, double_amplitudes)¶

“Return the uccsd generator by first generating single excitations and then generating the double excitations.

singlet_generator(packed_amplitudes, n_qubits, n_electrons)¶

Create a singlet uccsd generator for a system with n_electrons

This function generates a FermionOperator for a uccsd generator designed
to act on a single reference state consisting of n_qubits spin orbitals and n_electrons electrons, that is a spin singlet operator, meaning it conserves spin.
Args:
packed_amplitudes(list): List storing the unique single
and double excitation amplitudes for a singlet uccsd operator. The ordering lists unique single excitations before double excitations.
n_qubits(int): Number of spin-orbitals used to represent the system,
which also corresponds to number of qubits in a non-compact map.

n_electrons(int): Number of electrons in the physical system.

Returns:
generator(FermionOperator): Generator of the uccsd operator that
builds the uccsd wavefunction.
singlet_get_packed_amplitudes(single_amplitudes, double_amplitudes, n_qubits, n_electrons)¶

Convert amplitudes for use with singlet uccsd

The output list contains only those amplitudes that are relevant to singlet uccsd, in an order suitable for use with the function uccsd_singlet_generator.

Args:
single_amplitudes(ndarray): [N x N] array storing single excitation
amplitudes corresponding to t[i,j] * (a_i^dagger a_j - H.C.)
double_amplitudes(ndarray): [N x N x N x N] array storing double
excitation amplitudes corresponding to t[i,j,k,l] * (a_i^dagger a_j a_k^dagger a_l - H.C.)
n_qubits(int): Number of spin-orbitals used to represent the system,
which also corresponds to number of qubits in a non-compact map.

n_electrons(int): Number of electrons in the physical system.

Returns:
packed_amplitudes(list): List storing the unique single
and double excitation amplitudes for a singlet uccsd operator. The ordering lists unique single excitations before double excitations.
singlet_param_size(n_qubits, n_electrons)¶

Determine number of independent amplitudes for singlet uccsd

Args:
n_qubits(int): Number of qubits/spin-orbitals in the system n_electrons(int): Number of electrons in the reference state
Returns:
Number of independent parameters for singlet uccsd with a single reference.
uccsd_convert_amplitude_format(single_amplitudes, double_amplitudes)¶

Re-format single_amplitudes and double_amplitudes from ndarrays to lists, basically to allocate the corresponding index to the value.

up_index(index)¶

Return the index of spin up electron

hiqfermion.ansatzes.applyansatz module¶

The united module used to apply ansatzes to reference states.

class hiqfermion.ansatzes.applyansatz.apply_ansatz(ansatz='uccsd', state=None, ccsd_single_amps=None, ccsd_double_amps=None, rxrz_params=None, eng=None)¶

Bases: object

The class to apply ansatzes on initial states like HF states

Supported ansatzes:
 
rxrz:Apply circuit by \(Rx(\theta), Rz(\theta)\) and CNOT gates.
ry:Apply circuit by \(Ry(\theta)\) and CNOT gates.
ryrz:Apply circuit by \(Ry(\theta), Rz(\theta)\) and CNOT gates.
swaprz:Apply circuit by \(Rz(\theta)\) and Swap gates.
uccsd:Apply circuit by gates decomposed from ccsd ansatz.
Example how to use:
 
from hiqfermion.ansatzes import apply_ansatz
# Assume the Hatree-Fock state is already prepared here
wavefuntion = apply_ansatz(state = your_hf_state,
                           ansatz = 'rxrz',
                           rxrz_params = your_params,
                           eng = your_simulator_engine)
Example RxRz:
Allocate | Qureg[0]
Allocate | Qureg[1]
Allocate | Qureg[2]
Allocate | Qureg[3]
Rx(0.0) | Qureg[0]
Rz(0.1) | Qureg[0]
Rx(0.2) | Qureg[1]
Rz(0.3) | Qureg[1]
Rx(0.4) | Qureg[2]
Rz(0.5) | Qureg[2]
Rx(0.6) | Qureg[3]
Rz(0.7) | Qureg[3]
CX | ( Qureg[0], Qureg[1] )
CX | ( Qureg[1], Qureg[2] )
CX | ( Qureg[2], Qureg[3] )
Rx(0.8) | Qureg[0]
Rz(0.9) | Qureg[0]
Rx(1.0) | Qureg[1]
Rz(1.1) | Qureg[1]
Rx(1.2) | Qureg[2]
Rz(1.3) | Qureg[2]
Rx(1.4) | Qureg[3]
Rz(1.5) | Qureg[3]
Measure | Qureg[0]
Measure | Qureg[1]
Measure | Qureg[2]
Measure | Qureg[3]

hiqfermion.ansatzes.hartree_fock_state module¶

Building Hartree-Fock occupation numbers wave function. Transforms of occupation number wave function at different mapping of fermions to qubits is described in paper Sam McArdle et al., Quantum computational chemistry, arXiv:1808.10402.

class hiqfermion.ansatzes.hartree_fock_state.Hartree_Fock(molecule, fermion_transform='jordan_wigner')¶

Bases: object

Generate a hartree_fock initial state for the reference state Builds Hatree-Fock occupation number wave function for MolecularData object

or list or tuple with given number of electrons and qubits).

fermion_transform=jordan_wigner | parity | bravyi_kitaev | bravyi_kitaev_tree Transform which maps FermionOperator to QubitOperator is indicated in this parameter.
Raises:
TypeError: molecule must be MolecularData object,
List[int, int], or Tuple(int, int).
bit_str¶

Getter of the bit string that represented the initial statevector

hartree_fock()¶

Returns: Boolean list. ‘True’ corresponds to occupation nummber equal to 1, ‘False’ - 0. This list can be the argument in state preparation function for quantum circuit.

hiqfermion.ansatzes.hartree_fock_state.hartree_fock_state_preparation(eng, molecule, fermion_transform='Jordan_wigner')¶

Writing Hartree-Fock wave function in occupation numbers basis into quantum register. Args: eng - compiler engine.

molecule - MoleculaData object, List [n_electrons, n_qubits], or Tuple (n_electrons, n_qubits), where n_electrons(int) - number os electrons in molecule, n_qubits(int) - number of qubits necessary to describe the molecule. fermion_transform(str) - parameter indicating transform which maps FermionOperator to QubitOperator. fermion_transform = jordan_wigner | parity | bravyi_kitaev | bravyi_kitaev_tree

Returns: quantum register in which Hartree-Fock wave function in occupation numbers basis is written.

hiqfermion.ansatzes.variational_ansatz module¶

This module contains the definition of the base class of variational ansatzes. Extend this module to implement several typical and published ansatzes.

class hiqfermion.ansatzes.variational_ansatz.VariationalAnsatz(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: object

Base class for variational ansatzes.

build_ansatz(params, qureg=None)¶

Construct the variation ansatz for the quantum circuit.

Parameters:
  • params – numpy.ndarray[float] Circuit parameters of the ansatz.
  • qureg – quantum register Quantum register for the preparation of the ansatz.
Returns:

An ansatz circuit (or quantum state).
entangle_mapping¶

Return entanglement mapping, default to be full entanglement.

n_depth¶

Return the depth of the ansatz to be generated.

n_parameters¶

Number of parameters in the variational ansatz.

Returns:int The number of parameters needed for the ansatz.
n_qubits¶

Return the number of qubits in the quantum register.

param_index¶
Returns:The index of the parameters used in the preparation.
qureg¶
Returns:The quantum register.
single_qubit_operation¶

Number of single qubit operations performed during the ansatz preparation.

Returns:int The number of single qubit operations in the ansatz preparation.
two_qubits_operation¶

Number of two-qubit operations (CZ, CX or XX) performed during the ansatz preparation.

Returns:int The number of two-qubit operations in the ansatz preparation.

hiqfermion.ansatzes.vqe_hardware_efficient module¶

class hiqfermion.ansatzes.vqe_hardware_efficient.VQE_hardware_efficient(operator, ansatz, depth, params=None, entangle_mapping='linear', initial_state=None, opt_method='BFGS', tol=1e-05, eng=<projectq.cengines._main.MainEngine object>)¶

Bases: object

Variation Quantum Eigensolver algorithm with hardware-efficient state preparation. Arguments:

operator (QubitOperator) - Hamitonian of fermionic system tranformed to Qubit Operator. ansatz (str: ‘rxrz’ | ‘ryrz’) - type of rotational layers. depth (int) - depth of the rotation layers (default: 1). params (list[float]) - initial values of parameters. Deafut (None) - the parameters are generated from

uniform random diribution at interval (0, 2*pi)
entangle_mapping (dict or string) – dictionary of entanglement gates with format {control qubit:[list of target]}
or string, default ‘full’ indicate a full entanglement, ‘linear’ - linear entanglement)
initial_state (quantum register )– intitial state to which ansatz is applied. Default (None) - zeroed quantum register,
allocated before building quantum circuit.
opt_method (str) - method of classical optimization to pass into scipy.minimize function (default - ‘BFGS’).
If opt_method = ‘nak’, then Nakanishi optimizer is used instead of scipy function.

tol (float) - required tolerance to pass into scipy.minimize function (default - 1e-5). eng - simulator engine (default - MainEngine()).

Returns:
minimized energy of fermionic system.
energy_exp_value(param)¶
optimized_energy()¶
